titleStmt.title: Linköping Diocesan Library, Kl f 10
titleStmt.sponsor: Greek manuscripts in Sweden – a digitization and cataloguing project

publicationStmt.publisher: manuscripta.se: A Digital Catalogue of Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts in Sweden

supportDesc.foliation: Foliation mainly in ink in the upper right margin: 1a, 1b, 1–200 The blank leaves at the beginning and end of the textblock are foliated in pencil.

p.note: A label for Linköping Diocesan Library and a bookbinder’s stamp.

binding.p: Restored and rebound in white parchment by the Swedish National Archives bookbindery in .
binding.condition: In the process of rebinding the volume, the bookblock was also repaired; the leaves, badly frayed at the edges and fragile, were all remounted on silk gauze.

history.provenance: Owner’s note in Erik Benzelius the Younger’s hand on : Ex bibliotheca Er. Benzelii Er. filii. The signature Lucretii Palladii on may point to an earlier ownership.
history.acquisition: Purchased by Linköping Diocesan Library in as part of the Benzelius book collection.

note.p: The faded rubric has been filled in later, probably incorrectly, and the reference to Georgius Chrysococces’s Expositio in syntaxim Persarum in the margin is misleading. We thank Alberto Bardi for conveying this information to us; Bardi is at present working on a doctoral thesis and critical edition of the anonymous text.
For other manuscripts containing this text, see the article by Anne Tihon. Our manuscript, however, is not included in the list.
, which precede the beginning of the text, are blank except for an owner’s note.
is blank.

On there is a description on how to convert Byzantine, Persian, and Arabic calendars; here we find the phrase ὑποδείγματος οὖν χάριν ἐλάβομεν τὸ παρὸν ἔτος, ἤτοι τὸ ͵ϛϟιζ, the present year being , something which might be of interest as a terminus post quem for the text (or the copy).

One phrase is found in Georgios Gemisthos Plethon, De Astronomia: Μοῖραι μὲν ἐπὶ μοίρας πολλαπλασιαζόμεναι μοίρας ποιοῦσιν. Perhaps this is the short treatise by Plethon also preserved in Vindob. Phil. gr. 140, fol. 78–90 and Palat. gr. 278, fol. 135ff.
are blank.

msItem.title: Tables
msItem.rubric: Κανὼν μήκους τε καὶ πλάτους ἐν τοὺς ἰδίων πόλεων
msItem.incipit: σαφαλή ν οʹ β οʹ ντζουρμί μα μ ιθ μ

note.p:
A marginal comment on gives a reference to a passage in Hudson (1698–1712)
: C’est sans doute: Anonymi expositio totius mundi.
is incomplete and in a different hand.
is blank.
Tables drawn with a ruler and the outlines of the frame is traced.
are blank.

msItem.title: Hexapterygon Iudaicum
Expositio in Judaicum Sexalare, cum tabulis astronomicis subjunctis

note.p:
The text is a translation of and commentary to Immanuel ben Jacob Bonfils’s work Šes kenafayim. It is sometimes mistakenly attributed to Georgius Chrysococces; cf. Neugebauer (1975)
.

Cf. MS BL, Burney 92, fol. 226r (text no. 16). See also Theodorus Meliteniotes, De astronomia libri tres, Leurquin (1990–1993)
, ending similar to ch. 2, line 23. NB: only Books I–II are edited and available on TLG, so that it is possible that the extract in the ms comes from the third book.
On a larger initial and the rubric περὶ σεληνιακῶν ἐκλείψεις.

On a section on squared numbers: Τῶν μετὰ ῥητῶν τετραγόνων ἀριθμῶν εὐχερής, etc. Cf. Fabricius (1790–1809)
: De inventione quadraticorum laterum irrationabilium numerorum quadratorum.
Most of and are blank.
is blank.
More computational tables, framed in the same style as at and following.
is blank.
Further tables containing geographical names and distances.
are blank.
A digitization of Gustaf Wilhelm Gumaelius’s edition is available via urn:nbn:se:uu:diva-250532 and urn:nbn:se:uu:diva-249970.

msItem.title: De cyclis solis et lunae ad Andronicum
Uranologium
msItem.incipit: Ἐπειδὴ τοὺς ἄλλους τῶν νῦν σοφῶν παραδραμὼν

note.p: The red ink has all but disappeared; thus, the rubrics, subtitles, initials, and introductory lines of text in-between sections are not distinguishable. Cf. Denis Pétau’s printed text for the more complete text.
See also ms Bav. Vat. gr. 1059, fol. 205r–218v; 219r–223v (on Easter).
On there is a table with various letters/numbers, which is not found in the printed text.
Another text seems to be inserted on . The section on the calculation of Easter is picked up again in the last paragraph of (Τούτων δὴ οὖν τῶν κατὰ τὸν ἥλιον).

A comparison with Denis Pétau’s edition shows that its ending equals line 18 (expl. ἀξιόλογον ἀπεργαζομένης). In our ms there are another seven lines of text, beginning with σοὶ δ’ αὐτῷ συνετῶς γε ὄντι καὶ κρίνειν.

msItem.title: Calculations for the beginning of the year
msItem.incipit: Τῆς τοὺς ἔτους ἀρχῆς ἄλλης καὶ ἄλλης παρ’ ἑτέροις
msItem.explicit: ἀπὸ τῆς προγεγωνυίας συνόδου ἡμέρας ιδʹ τῆς σελήνης
msItem.note: The rubric is faded. Text not identified.

msItem.title: De Paschate
msItem.note: The rubrics are faded, but the table seems to be the one that Denis Pétau presents with the caption Τὸ διορθωθὲν Πασχάλιον ὑπὸ Νικηφόρου φιλοσόφου τοῦ Γρηγορᾶ, περὶ οὗ ὁ Ἀργυρὸς ἐν τῇ ἀνωτέρῳ ῥηθείση μεθόδῳ διελάμβανε.

note.p: A table; not clear how it relates to the previous text.
are blank.

msItem.title: De radice quadrato
msItem.rubric: [...] εὑρέσεως τῶν τετραγωνικῶν πλευρῶν τῶν μὴ ῥητῶν τετραγώνων ἀριθμῶν
msItem.incipit: Τῶν μὲν ῥητῶν τετραγώνων ἀριθμῶν εὐχερής ἐστιν
msItem.note: There is a large lacuna in the text due to disarray and loss of leaves. The manuscript text breaks off at πλεῖον τῶν ηʹ λεῖψις γὰρ ἐπὶ λεῖψιν and picks up again at ἐπεὶ γὰρ ἡ συγκεφαλαίωσις τοῦ πλήθους.

msItem.title: On the astrolabe
msItem.incipit: Εἰ βούλει γινώσκειν τὴν τοῦ ἀστρολάβου μέθοδον
msItem.note: Several shorter texts concerning the astrolabe and calculations. The rubrics are faded or absent; cf. Armand Delatte’s edition.

msItem.title: De cyclis solis et lunae ad Andronicum
Uranologium
msItem.incipit: Ἐπειδὴ τοὺς ἄλλους τῶν νῦν σοφῶν παραδραμὼν
msItem.explicit: καὶ τί ἂν εἴη τὸ αἴτιον τῆς κατὰ τὴν

note.p: The table on ought to belong to one of the texts by Isaac Argyros, either the preceding or the following one, but not clear how.

The text breaks off early. This is another instance of the text already present on
.

msItem.title: Opera
Περὶ καταρχῶν
Excerptum, De agricultura
msItem.incipit: Σελήνης οὔσης ἐν Κριῷ συμφέρει φυτεύειν

note.p: Cf. the text Περὶ γεωργίας in Scorialensis Iota. R. 14, fol. 179, edited by Carlo Oreste Zuretti. In our ms there are another three lines of text, on the auspicious time for bloodletting etc.: οὔσης ἐν Ταύρῳ, Λέοντι καὶ Τοξότῃ, δεῖ ποιεῖν τὰς τῶν αἱμάτων ἀφαιρέσεις· ἐν δὲ Ζυγῷ Σκορπίῳ Ὑδροχόῳ μεθ’ ὑποσταλῆς· ἐν δὲ Κριῷ Διδύμῳ Αἰγοκέρωτι Καρκίνῳ Ἰχθύσι Παρθένῳ οὐ δόλως ποιεῖν δεῖ.

msItem.title: On celestial phenomena
msItem.incipit: Ὁ οὐρανὸς σφαιροειδής ἐστι κύκλῳ περιέχων τὴν γήν
msItem.explicit: διὰ τὸ ὀξὺ τῆς τοῦ πόλου κινήσεως

note.p: The greater part of the text equals Stefan Weinstock’s edition based on Oxoniensis Seldenianus 16 (=Seldenianus Supra 17), fol. 177v–179v, except for a lacuna in our ms from οἱ δὲ Ἰχθύες ἐν ἁμφοτέροις τοῖς ἡμισφαιρίοις to πάντα μὲν οὖν τὰ προδεδηλωμένα ἄστρα. In the first few lines there is a reference to Aratus’s Phaenomena.

msItem.incipit: Σύνοδος πρὸς ἥλιον ὅτε γεγένηται ἐν τῷ αὐτῷ ζωδίῳ

msItem.title: Vita Arati et varia de Arato
Prooemium in Arati phaenomena
msItem.explicit: Ὠρίων δύνει δὲ Ὀφιοῦχος ἕως γονάτων
msItem.note: In Ernst Maass’s edition the title for section 6bis is Ποῖα τῶν ζῳδίων συνανατέλλουσι καὶ συγκαταδύνουσι τοῖς ἐν τῷ ζωιδιακῷ ιβʹ ζῳδίοις, and he refers to Aratus Phaenomena vv. 569–731 for this passage.

msItem.title: Vita Arati et varia de Arato
Prooemium in Arati phaenomena
msItem.incipit: ἀρκτικὸς κύκλος τέμνει ζώιδια ιʹ Ἡνιόχου γόνατα
msItem.note: Ernst Maass refers to Aratus Phaenomena vv. 480–524 for this passage.

msItem.incipit: ἥλιος δι’ ὅλου τοῦ ἐνιαυτοῦ τουτέστι διὰ τξεʹ δʹʹ

note.p: Astrological computations; text(s) not identified.
Lines 5–12 on probably in another hand. A later addition perhaps.
A table framed in the same style as at and following.
On the verso, six compass diagrams with intersecting lines and geometrical shapes, presenting the zodiac in the margin to the circle.
are blank.

collation.p: Original composition not possible to reconstruct due to extensive restoration.

handDesc.handNote: A typical scholarly Renaissance hand writing in a minute module in light brown ink, now partly faded and hardly legible; astrological/nomical signs are employed frequently, as well as abbreviations; despite the compression, some letters are flourished in their ligatures and others a little enlarged and made more prominent, such as Taus and Etas. In the tables, the minute letters appear compressed in the sense of their height.
A less orderly and more wavy hand; the ink is darker, the module slightly bigger; it is probably also responsible for the correction at . On a scholion perhaps in a different hand.

Set in a different framework for the tables, in a slightly darker ink, is also very small in module but slightly squatter in appearance; the Ksi is drawn in many curves; it is difficult to say if it is the same hand writing all these tables, but in any case the style is very homogeneous.

Still more minute and compressed, with a forward motion impressed to it by the slanting chis whose descending strokes echo the acute accents sprinkled above the line. The Gamma is often looped while the ligature Epsilon-Ksi is sometimes enlarged out of proportion (e.g. on ). The symbol for sun is used most frequently. This scribe occasionally displays the Epsilon ad ombelico. He uses simple initials enlarged in the margin; cf. the hand of Isidore Cardinal of Kiev, RGK
.
Very similar to Hand A , though the writing of these tables is less precise, even somewhat sloppy.
Perhaps different hands, one writing a very spidery small minuscule, but relaxing into more cursive an relaxed segments. Another writhing in a darker brown-grey ink. Unclear.

decoDesc.p:
The rubrication of titles, subtitles, and initials has in most cases faded to all but total illegibility. This applies also for the outlines and details in many of the tables. There are traces of decorated initials e.g. at
.

history.origin: Probably mid-15th c. origin. A terminus post quem is assured by way of Michael Chrysococces’s text on , which was composed in .

revisionDesc.change: Changing status from draft to published
